entry.title: Checklist for Service Procurement Integration SAP Fieldglass, Ariba and S/4HANA Solutions
entry.content:
Welcome to the Checklist for Service Procurement Integration SAP Fieldglass, Ariba and S/4HANA Solutions

Target Audience

This blog is for implementors and administrators from customer and partner organizations. It’s a living document that will be updated regularly, so bookmark this page and revisit for the latest insights. Got a question? Drop it in the Q&A section at the bottom of the page!

Why Service Procurement Integration Matters

Did you know that employees now make up only 58% of workforce spend? The other 42% goes to external resources. This data, from Services Procurement Insights: The Big Reveal, underscores the rising importance of managing external services efficiently.

In today’s business landscape, organizations come from diverse backgrounds and unique journeys. This heterogeneity can make service procurement integration challenging. But here’s the good news: streamlining your Purchase Requisition (PR), Purchase Order (PO), Service Entry Sheets (SES), and Invoice processes can give you tighter control over your procurement lifecycle.

Why is this critical? For one, you don’t want to fall victim to scams where fraudulent invoices got paid. Tight integration can help you avoid paying for services without authorized POs and verified proof of delivery. (funny but real story)

The Benefits of Integration

Integrating PR/PO, SES, and Invoice processes isn’t just about compliance; it’s about transformation. Here’s what you stand to gain:

  • Fraud Prevention: Never pay invoices without an authorized PO and proof of service delivery.
  • Enhanced Visibility: Get a complete picture of your service procurement spend.
  • Improved Compliance: Stay audit-ready and meet regulatory standards.
  • Streamlined Performance: Reduce inefficiencies and manual interventions.

Your Options for Integration

Here are three solid solutions for integrating end-to-end service procurement applications:

  1. ERP Add-on by ASAPIO
    • For customers on SAP ECC or S/HANA MM-SRV
  2. 22K Solution
    • For Customers who prefers direct integration between SAP Fieldglass and SAP S/4HANA (lean services)
  3. 4R2 Solution
    • For Customers who like to integrate SAP Fieldgalss and SAP S/4HANA(lean services) via SAP Ariba

Questions to Answer Before You Start

Before diving into implementation, take a moment to reflect on these key questions:

  1. What cost objects will your services spend be allocated to?
    • Think cost centers, internal orders, maintenance orders or projects. Clarifying this early will guide your financial postings.
  2. What version of SAP S/4HANA are you using?
    • Features and compatibility often hinge on your specific SAP S/4HANA version (MM-SRV vs lean services a key decision criteria).  For customers who are adopting SAP S/4HANA Cloud, they will automatically start only on lean services however many customers on-prem or private cloud may need to take care of this migration.  MM-SRV to lean services migration can be found here: Link: https://me.sap.com/notes/2906140
  3. Why can integration be complicated?
    • Integration complexity grows exponentially due to:
      • Types of cost objects
      • Business documents (PR, PO, SES, Invoice)
      • Actions like create, revise, or close
  4. What about performance considerations?
    • A major bottleneck can be the number of SES entries per single PO line item. Plan your system design to avoid performance issues.

Let’s Hear From You!

Have questions, thoughts, or tips to share? Drop them in the comments below, and let’s start a conversation!

entry.title: Content Enricher & Request Reply in sap cpi
entry.content:
SAP CPI Request Reply & Content Enricher:

  • Request-Reply :
  • Description: Calls an external receiver system synchronously and retrieves a response.
  • Use Cases: Certain integration scenarios require the Cloud Integration tenant to communicate with an external service, retrieve data, and further process it. In such cases, you can use the request-reply step as an exit point to connect to the external service.
  • Content Enricher:
  • Function: The content enricher adds the content of a payload with the original message during an integration process. This process combines the two separate messages into a single enhanced payload.
  • Purpose: This feature enables you to make external calls during an integration process to obtain additional data.
  • Here two tabs are there 
    1.General: we give meaningful name.
    2.Processing: here we can perform the operations.
    Aggregation Algorithm: Here two options presents.
  • You can choose between two strategies to enrich these two payloads into a single message:
  • Combine: Combines the original and lookup messages. You cannot define any rules for combining messages with this strategy.
  • Enrich: Enables you to define paths to specific nodes and key elements within the original and lookup messages. The original message is enriched with data from the lookup message based on these paths.
  • Original Message: The first message in the integration flow.
  • Path to Node: Path to the reference node within the original message.
  • Key Element: Key element within the original message.
  • Lookup Message: The message obtained by making an external call during the integration process.
  • Path to Node: Path to the reference node within the lookup message.
  • Key Element: Key element within the lookup message.
  • Example: Using OData Adapters
  • OData Adapter: This adapter exchanges data with a remote component that might be outside the scope of SAP.
    https://services.odata.org/V2/OData/OData.svc/
  • Scenario: We will use a product catalog as the resource for the original message (obtained using a request-reply step with an OData adapter) and add to incoming payload place a supplier list as the resource for the lookup message (also obtained using a Content enricher step with an OData adapter).
  • Enrichment Strategy:
  • First Scenario: Combine
  • This option simply combines the two payloads without any modification.
  • Second Scenario: Enrich
  • This option merges the two payloads into a single payload based on specified conditions.
    Outputs:1. Combine

    2.    ENRICH:

entry.title: Service procurement end to end Integration with SAP Fieldglass and SAP S/4HANA(22K)
entry.content:
SAP’s S/4HANA and Fieldglass solutions offer a comprehensive approach to streamline the end-to-end process(via scope item 22K)—from job postings to payments for contingent, SOW and SOW workers. Let’s dive into the key process flow, business benefits, and standout features that make this integration a game-changer.

Key Process Flow

  1. Create Purchase Requisitions: Generate purchase requisitions in SAP S/4HANA for each job posting and statement of work after creating a work order.
  2. Approve Purchase Requisitions: (Optional) Approve requisitions directly in SAP S/4HANA.
  3. Create Purchase Orders: Convert approved requisitions into purchase orders in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  4. Approve Purchase Orders: (Optional) Approve purchase orders within SAP S/4HANA.
  5. Submit Time for Approval: External workers log their time in SAP Fieldglass, which is then submitted for managerial approval.
  6. Create Service Entry Sheets: Generate service entry sheets in SAP S/4HANA. Approval is optional but can be enabled with minor configuration tweaks.
  7. Propose Invoices: Suppliers receive invoice proposals based on submitted time data in SAP Fieldglass.
  8. Post Invoices: After supplier approval, invoices are posted in SAP S/4HANA.

 

Business Benefits

Integrating SAP S/4HANA and SAP Fieldglass delivers numerous advantages, including:

  • Timely and Automated Payments: Reduce the cost and risk of outstanding payments with automated processes.
  • Accurate and Compliant Booking: Ensure precise recording of time and expenses for the external workforce.
  • Enhanced Productivity: Streamline workflows with integrated purchase requisitions, purchase orders, service entry sheets, and supplier invoices.
  • Improved Data Consistency: Achieve seamless data replication from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Fieldglass for reliable system-wide consistency.

Key Features of the End-to-End Process

1. Faster and Accurate Close with Self-Billing

Self-billing, also known as Evaluated Receipt Settlement (ERS), automates the settlement of goods and service receipts. With ERS, suppliers agree not to submit invoices for purchase order transactions. Instead, the system automatically posts invoice documents based on purchase order and goods receipt data, eliminating invoice variances.

 

Benefits of Self-Billing:

  • Automatic settlement of service entry sheets
  • Prevention of invoice variances
  • Faster transaction closure
  • Elimination of non-value-added work
  • Centralized tax management

SAP S/4HANA’s scope item 22K supports this feature, allowing selective activation via supplier master data (look for ERS checkbox on supplier master data in SAP S/4HANA which will be replicated to SAP Fieldglass automatically via MDI).

2. Automatic Accruals Management

SAP S/4HANA integrates accruals management for unapproved time and expenses recorded in SAP Fieldglass. This feature ensures compliance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and enables timely cost and revenue recognition.

 

Value Proposition:

  • Recognize costs and revenue without delays
  • Ensure compliance with accounting standards

By leveraging SAP’s integrated solutions, organizations can streamline workforce procurement, improve accuracy, and drive operational excellence. Whether it’s automating self-billing or managing accruals, the possibilities are transformative. Ready to explore these capabilities?

entry.title: Optimizing Production Order Process: Leveraging SAP BTP Event Mesh for Decoupling Inbound Scenario
entry.content:
We were working on a scenario for a greenfield implementation project, with the initial phase focused on a newly built plant. The technologies used included SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud, Integration Suite on Cloud Foundry, and a third-party Manufacturing Execution System (MES). The scenario revolved around the production order process, encompassing activities like backflush and confirmations.

For confirmations, we employed the Auto GR (Goods Receipt) process. From a technical standpoint, we planned to implement API-based development and integrations, adhering to SAP best practices. Before diving into the technical solution, let me first provide the context of the problem and the reason for the change.

In the initial phase, the design dictated that SAP S/4HANA would expose only the OData APIs required for the production order process, while the MES team would handle the remaining responsibilities. You may already be questioning this approach, and rightfully so—I completely agree. There was indeed a flaw in the design process, but by the time it was identified, it was too late to implement major changes. We had no choice but to proceed with the existing design, while remaining open to revisiting it in the future.

Problem Statement: We implemented the design as planned, where the MES system utilized Azure technologies to make calls and process confirmations and backflushes. Initially, everything functioned well due to the low volume of data. However, as the shop floor operations scaled and multiple systems began simultaneously triggering GR (Goods Receipt) and backflush requests, the system started throwing errors.

The issue stemmed from API-level locking inherent in SAP’s design, where only one request could process a production order at a time. If a request was already being processed, subsequent ones failed due to the lock. Additionally, the second flaw was that the MES team could only see the default error response code provided by the OData API. This lack of visibility left the S/4HANA team unable to provide effective support or handle exceptions.

The SAP S/4HANA team could not provide support or implement exception handling due to the absence of an application layer or any development and integration mechanisms to monitor errors effectively. After analyzing the issue, we requested the MES team to implement a 5-second delay for processing confirmations and backflushes. While this solution initially worked for a few orders (around 10), it quickly failed under higher data volumes, as the same error reoccurred.

To address this recurring issue, we brainstormed alternative approaches and proposed introducing Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) into EDA into the landscape. This approach involved leveraging SAP Event Mesh on SAP BTP and building an integration layer using SAP Integration Suite to process the data efficiently. The resulting high-level architecture offered a scalable and resilient solution to overcome these challenges.

 

Let me explain the steps we followed to implement the solution.

Prerequisites

Before proceeding, ensure that SAP Event Mesh (EM) is activated in the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) with the necessary roles and authorizations. Once the prerequisites were met, we completed the following configurations.

It is important to note that when activating EM, you must create a service key specific to the Event Mesh. To receive data, you need to share the service key credentials for EM. A common mistake I have observed is sharing the Cloud Integration service keys instead of the Event Mesh service key. These two are not the same, and the service key in SAP BTP serves a specific purpose.

Steps to Configure Event Mesh

  1. Create a Queue in Event Mesh:
    • The queue serves as a receiver for the data to be processed by the system.
  2. Bind the CPI Endpoint to the Queue:
    • Configure the integration flow endpoint in the SAP Cloud Integration Suite as a webhook to the queue. This ensures that incoming messages from the queue are routed to the integration flow for processing into SAP S/4HANA.
  3. Create a Dead Queue:
    • Typically, dead queues are used to handle exception messages. However, in this scenario, we repurposed the dead queue to log and reprocess lock errors. I’ll explain this usage further.
  4. Configure the Integration Flow:
    • Initially, we considered creating a custom integration flow to handle this, but we found pre-packaged integration content that streamlined the implementation. The package is available in the SAP Integration Suite Discover section under the name “Replay Messages from Queues via SAP Event Mesh”.

Using the Pre-Packaged Integration Content

The package contains four artifacts, each with a specific purpose. However, we utilized only three artifacts as there was no need to leverage value mapping which was the fourth artifact.

  1. Retrieving Messages from SAP Event Mesh to JMS:
    • This integration flow retrieves messages from SAP Event Mesh and sends them to the JMS queue.
  2. JMS Router for SAP Event Mesh Messages:
    • The core integration flow routes messages from the JMS queue based on their type or purpose.
  3. Processing Messages:
    • This flow processes the JMS messages retrieved from SAP Event Mesh and sends them to SAP S/4HANA.

By utilizing this pre-packaged content, we eliminated the need to develop a custom solution from scratch, saving significant time and effort. The setup allowed us to handle and process messages efficiently while addressing exceptions such as lock errors through the configured dead queue.

Exposing an Event Mesh (EM) Endpoint to Receive Data

Once a queue is created in SAP Event Mesh, you need to use a prefix to publish or consume the data. Instead of duplicating existing content, I recommend referring to this Exposing EM Endpoint that provides detailed steps for exposing an Event Mesh endpoint.

What We Achieved Compared to the Initial Problem

After implementing the Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) and exposing the Event Mesh endpoint, we addressed several challenges outlined in the initial problem statement. Here’s what we achieved:

  1. Added a Technology Layer to Monitor the Process:
    • By introducing SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh, we gained better visibility and control over the transaction flow.
  1. Decoupled the Process Using EDA:
    • The MES system was no longer directly coupled to SAP S/4HANA, reducing dependencies and bottlenecks.
  1. Streamlined Transactions from MES to S/4HANA:
    • Transactions flowed seamlessly from the MES system into SAP S/4HANA, thanks to the event-driven approach.
  1. Eliminated MES Exception Handling for Lock Issues:
    • The MES system no longer handled API lock issues, as the Event Mesh took over and returned 204 responses (success status).
  1. Enhanced Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite:
    • All S/4HANA transactions received from the MES system could now be monitored and managed effectively in the SAP Integration Suite.
  1. Automatic Processing of Lock Issues with Dead Queue:
    • Using the Dead Queue concept, API lock issues were processed automatically until successful, ensuring consistency.
  1. Integrated Exception Handling for Data Issues:
    • Alerts for data-related issues were integrated, allowing the data team to address problems promptly.

How We Used the Dead Queue to Process Messages

The Dead Queue concept was applied with a unique approach. Here’s how it worked:

  1. Handling API Lock Issues:
    • When multiple transactions were processed simultaneously, any transaction encountering an API lock was written to the Dead Queue.
  2. Custom Integration Flow:
    • A copy of the standard integration artifact was created, designed to read messages directly from the Dead Queue.
    • The custom flow repeatedly processed the messages until they were successfully posted.
  3. Outcome:
    • This approach allowed us to monitor and handle transactions with lock issues effectively.
    • We could tally the total number of messages processed from the MES system to SAP S/4HANA, ensuring all transactions were accounted for.

Solution to COGI Errors and Decoupling GR and Backflush

After rigorous testing, we concluded that the EDA architecture effectively resolved the primary problem. However, we encountered COGI errors due to standard BAPI locks during the final posting to S/4HANA. To address this, we implemented the following solution:

  1. Decoupling GR and Backflush Processes We introduced changes to separate the Goods Receipt (GR) and Backflush processes, reducing contention at the BAPI level.
      • Decouple GR and Backflush Process for a detailed explanation of how we decoupled the processes.

Final Results

With these enhancements, we successfully processed hundreds of orders simultaneously. By leveraging Event-Driven Architecture and decoupling critical processes, we significantly reduced system dependencies and resource contention.

For high-volume, scalable implementations, I strongly recommend using EDA and decoupling processes wherever possible. This approach not only reduces system dependencies but also enhances performance, monitoring, and resilience.

Note: I have not purposefully included the technical details are there are many blogs from our experts detailing how to use the EM. Incase if you have specific questions please reach out to me. 

Regards 

HS

entry.title: Welcome to the Integration Group in SAP Community!
entry.content:
We’re thrilled to announce the launch of the Integration Group, a dedicated space within SAP Community where integration developers can connect, collaborate, and innovate.  Whether you’re a seasoned professional or just starting your integration journey, this group is designed to support your efforts in accelerating innovation through integration. 

What’s in it for you? 

This group serves as your hub for: 

  • Asking questions and staying updated with latest feature releases for SAP Integration Suite and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.  
  • Exploring and discussing topics like application integration, API lifecycle management, and event streaming. 
  • Sharing your expertise and learning from fellow community members. 
  • Collaborating on ideas and projects that push the boundaries of integration innovation. 

Getting Started 

Here’s how to make the most of this group: 

  1. Join the Group: While anyone can browse the content, you need to join the group to contribute and participate actively. By joining, you’ll also receive notifications for updates on subscribed content. 
  • Need help? Check out the Getting Started content in the Help section. 
  1. Follow the Rules: We’re committed to maintaining a respectful and productive environment. Make sure to follow the SAP Community Rules of Engagement. 
  • Our moderators will ensure that discussions remain relevant and valuable to all members. 
  1. Label Your Content: When creating discussion posts or blogs, create labels for your content using Message User Tags to label your content. This helps improve organization and makes it easier for others to find and engage with your contributions.  

Shape the Group’s Future 

This group will evolve based on your input. We’re eager to hear your ideas for topics, content formats, or features that you’d like to see here. Share your suggestions freely - this is your community, and your voice matters! 

Let’s Innovate Together 

The Integration Group is built to bring people together, engage in meaningful conversations, and drive innovation in integration. We encourage you to participate actively, share your knowledge, and collaborate with peers. 

With that, welcome to your new integration hub. Let’s build, share, and grow together. Join the group now and start your journey with us! 

We can’t wait to see how this group grows and evolves into a collaborative space for integration enthusiasts through your contributions. Let’s innovate together!

entry.title: Feel free to join the new Integration group in our community
entry.content:
You may have seen the announcement from SAP's Chief Product Officer for SAP Integration Suite about the launch of a new Integration group, a dedicated space within our SAP Community meant to collaborate across different integration topics.

Feel free to join this Integration group to exchange information, ask questions, post blogs posts etc. across different integration topics all under one hood, such as SAP Integration Suite and its capabilities like Cloud Integration, API Management, (Advanced) Event Mesh, Graph, etc., interface development as well as monitoring and error handling with SAP Application Interface Framework, integration strategy, etc.

What does this now mean for the topic pages such as the one for SAP Integration Suite?

Well, the topic pages remain, here you find all relevant information about the respective products like product documentation, roadmap information, new features, learning information, best practices, etc.

However, when accessing community content and creating new content, we have changed the navigation to ease the collaboration within the new Integration group. Let's check how this looks like for the SAP Integration Suite topic page.

The Community content menu now points to the new group. So, from here you can directly navigate to the Integration group.

The Create content has three entries:

  • You can Create a Question: this will create a new question below Technology Q&A which is automatically tagged with SAP Integration Suite. Note, this question won't show up in the group.
  • You can Start a Discussion: this is similar to asking a question but this time you navigate to the Discussion board of the Integration group.
  • You can Create a Blog Post: here you navigate to the Blog posts board of the Integration group where you are able to create a blog post which will then show up in the group.

By intention, we do not directly enter the discussion editor or the blog posts editor of the group but rather open the boards so that you are aware that you have navigated to the group. When you create a discussion or a blog post, don't forget to tag your post. Your content will show up in the group and depending on the tag also in the respective Community pages.

If you still like to access the Community pages, we have now added all links into the navigation pane of the topic page. Within the Community pages, you can also post content, but unfortunately this won't be shown in the group.

Enjoy collaboration! See you in the group then.

entry.title: SAP’s Shift to Open Standards – A Strategic Move or Happy Accident?
entry.content:
Introduction

11 years ago, when I began my career as an SAP Integration consultant, often times when I google for work related research, I’d see results from SAP SCN and SAP help pages only. Today, what has changed is that, I see results on the same question/theme, being addressed by blogs/sites that have nothing to do with the SAP tool/platform on which, I am working currently. But the answer/content that I read there somehow turns out to be highly relevant to the issue/topic I am researching currently, on the SAP tool/platform that I am working with.

Upon reflection, as a broader trend across various SAP products and platforms, there seem to be a strong adoption of industry standard technologies, protocols & frameworks, which in many cases are open-source as well. While SAP’s proprietary standards have influenced others in the ERP industry for a long time, this remarkable departure and SAP gravitating towards standards in many aspects, is something that prompted me to connect the dots and to share with the community. In this post, I’d like to list a few of the areas, where I have noticed this trend:

1) Integrations:

  • REST, ODATA APIs encouraged instead of bapi/rfc, proxy, Idoc
  • Edge Integration Cell is based on Kubernetes containers, which is industry standard to package & distribute workloads, a necessary evolution from the SOA style platform that SAP PI/PO used to be.
  • Well documented APIs in Business Accelerator Hub than in PI/PO days
  • SAP Cloud Integration being based on Apache camel open-source framework. By extension, this facilitates direct support for camel expression language as well as various enterprise integration patterns – like splitter, router, gather, join in the Iflow design.
  • Integration advisor’s crowdsourced ML based mapping recommendation, supports conversion of canonical data model to standard EDI formats like ANSI X12, EDIFACT and vice-versa.

2) Platform choices:

  • Choice of hyperscaler platforms – Azure, AWS, etc. allowed to be exercised by the customer. This makes SAP an ERP Software selling company.
  • Runtime environments such as Cloud Foundry & Kyma are open-source. (Further reading)

3) Application Development:

  • Support for Java, JavaScript (node js), in addition to ABAP as tech stacks. This is a big step in utilizing coding skills available in the market.
  • BAS and Build Code being Git friendly.

4) Broader BTP services:

  • Application logging service in BTP uses Kibana (an open-source project)
  • KServe, an open-source Model Inference Platform on Kubernetes, being used behind the scenes by AI Core.
  • Redis & Postgres hyperscaler offering in addition to the proprietary HANA DB.
  • Evolution of UX/UI from proprietary SAP GUI to Fiori / UI5 based front-end. OpenUI5 is a JavaScript UI Framework released by SAP under the Apache 2.0 license.

Conclusion

SAP’s growing adoption of open-source technologies and industry standards doesn’t just seem to be accidental, but based on a conscious vision, as reflected in the SAP Open-source Manifesto. This shift benefits both customers and developers by fostering interoperability, flexibility, and innovation in the SAP ecosystem.

Disclaimer: My observations are based on my exposure to SAP BTP & ERP only and this trend might not apply or apply differently across SAP’s other product lines.

entry.title: Mapping the Source structure to Target structure using Groovy Script.
entry.content:
Hey Readers, It's been a long time since I posted a blog again! But believe me I just came up with an interesting topic. I am sure at one or the other point it will be useful! 😀

Do you know that we can map the data and convert it to json format without using palette options?
 🤔 Obviously yes!

In this blog lets see about how to map the data and convert back to json format without using the message mapping and converters in integration flow.

Of course, I am not very good at coding 😅 but yes! I follow some simple tricks to make our work easy in our day to day life.

Objective:
Map the incoming data to target structure and convert back to JSON format using Groovy Script.

Source Structure:

{
    "id": "456783421908765z",
    "time": "2025-01-13T08:25:37.066663700Z",
    "data":
    {
        "moduleName": "Create",
        "firstName": "SAP",
        "lastName": "CPI",
        "startDate": "02/16/2025",
        "endDate": "03/31/2025",
        "code": "1234"
    }
}

Target Structure:

{

       "uniqueID": "456783421908765z" ,
        "module": "Create",
        "fName": "SAP",
        "lName": "CPI",
        "startDate": "02/16/2025",
        "endDate": "03/31/2025"
}

Integration Flow Details:
Step1: Lets build a simple integration flow by adding a groovy script.

Step2: For capturing the incoming payload lets create a property in the content modifier. If the value is true then capture the payload else not.

Step3:
Ah! Our most important code in this blog... Lets add some pieces of code to do mapping in groovy without using palette options.

def Message processData(Message message)
{
def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;

//get properties
def log = message.getProperty("log") as String;

//log input payload
if(log == "true")
{
if(messageLog != null)
{
messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("Input Payload", body.toString(), "text/plain");
}
}

//extract data from the json
Map jsonMsg = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body);

def id = jsonMsg.id;
def moduleName = jsonMsg.data.moduleName;
def firstName = jsonMsg.data.firstName;
def lastName = jsonMsg.data.lastName;
def sDate = jsonMsg.data.startDate;
def eDate = jsonMsg.data.endDate;

//construct Target payload
def jbuilder = new JsonBuilder();
def jslurpur = new JsonSlurper();

jbuilder
{
uniquelD id
module moduleName
fname firstName
lname lastName
startDate sDate
endDate eDate
}

output_payload = jslurpur.parseText(jbuilder.toString());
message.setBody(JsonOutput.toJson(output_payload));
return message;

}

Execution:

Finally, Its time to execute! I have executed the code  by using groovy IDE.

Tadaaa! The Output is here! 🤗

You can also see the input payload attached on the bottom right side of the page under
'Attachments'.


Okay then, I hope this blog is informative! Let's catch up on the next blog.


please feel free to drop a comment and don't forget to follow me on linkedin
Mounika - Linkedin 

Thanks & Regards,
Mounika.

entry.title: Your Path to SAP Integration Suite Certification: Courses, Exam Prep, and Expert Tips
entry.content:
Certifications are a great way to upskill and validate your expertise. If you are a developer and work within the integration space, the key certification to consider is the SAP Certified Associate - Integration Developer. This guide will tell you more about this exam and what to do to prepare.  

 

About the Exam 

Information about the exams, including the number of questions, cut scores and sample questions are published on learning.sap.com/certifications. The recommended certification for developers working in the integration space is the SAP Certified Associate - Integration Developer.  

The certification website gives you a breakdown of topic areas covered in the exam and their weight, so you know what to focus on. Check the exam page for the most up to date information. 

The certifications are valid for 12 months. You can extend the certification by 12 more months by completing an assessment. You will receive a heads up from SAP to let you know when it’s time to renew your certification. 

 

How to Schedule the Exam 

You can schedule your SAP Integration Suite certification exam in two ways: 

If You Have a Learning Hub Subscription 

With an SAP Learning Hub subscription, you receive four exam attempts per year as part of your plan. You can use these attempts to take up to four different certification exams or to retake an exam if needed. 

To schedule your exam: 

  1. Log in to learning.sap.com. 
  2. Find the certification exam you want to take. 
  3. Click Schedule. This will take you to the Questionmark certification portal, where you can view and manage your exam dates. 
  4. On the Questionmark certification portal, click Exam dashboard from the top-level navigation. Then click Schedule an exam.  
  5. Find the certification exam you want to take from the list (there are a lot, and it’s easier to do a control / command + F). Click the calendar icon to select the desired date and time. Then click Save Appointment. 
  6. To view your scheduled exams, click Exam Appointments from the top-level navigation.  

If You Don’t Have a Learning Hub Subscription 

If you don’t have a Learning Hub subscription, you can purchase a set of certification attempts.  

You have three purchase options: 

  • One certification attempt, available to purchase here. 
  • Two certification attempts, including 10 hours of practice system access with it, available to purchase here. 
  • A bundle of six attempts (usable for different certifications or exam retakes if needed), available to purchase here. 

Once purchased, follow the scheduling instructions on the website to book your exam. 

 

How to Stay Certified 

The SAP Integration Suite certification is valid for one year. To maintain your certification, you’ll need to renew it annually. 

  • If you have a Learning Hub subscription: You can renew your certification by completing a short assessment covering the latest SAP Integration Suite innovations. 
  • If you don’t have a Learning Hub subscription: You must purchase a certification attempt and retake the full exam. You can do so here. 

For more details, visit the SAP certification renewal guide. 

 

What to Study for the SAP Integration Suite Certification: Learning Paths  

The best way to prepare for the exam is to take learning paths. Completing the learning paths along with their quizzes and hands on exercises will provide the knowledge and practice needed to pass the certification. Below are the recommended learning paths to pass the SAP Integration Suite certification exam: 

  • Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud 
  • Developing with SAP Integration Suite learning path  

The learning paths take about 12 hours to complete, and they cover all relevant topics you need to pass the exam.  

 

Additional Resources to Support Your Learning 

While the learning paths cover all the important topics required to pass your certification exam, it’s always helpful to reinforce your learning with additional resources and hands-on practice. Here are some valuable materials to deepen your understanding of SAP Integration Suite and boost your confidence before the exam. 

Live Sessions – SAP Integration Suite 

Join expert-led live sessions on SAP Integration Suite to get hands-on guidance, ask questions, and stay updated on the latest developments. See the upcoming live sessions here. You need the Learning Hub subscription to access these sessions. 

SAP CodeJams 

Participate in free CodeJam sessions, where you can practice SAP Integration Suite in a collaborative, hands-on environment. These sessions are ideal for gaining real-world experience and troubleshooting with experts. More info here. 

 

SAP Integration Suite Missions & Tutorials 

Explore interactive missions and tutorials on the SAP Developers site. These step-by-step guides will help you apply what you’ve learned and build confidence before taking the certification exam. 

 

Your SAP Integration Suite Exam Prep Checklist 

Follow these steps to maximize your chances of passing the exam on your first attempt. 

  1. Understand the exam structure.  
    • Review the certification webpage to learn about the exam topics and their weight, so you know where to focus your studies. 
    • Familiarize yourself with the exam format, including the number of questions, time limit, and passing score. 
  2. Follow the recommended learning journey 
    • Complete all the recommended learning paths outlined in this post. 
    • Make sure to complete all hands-on activities and quizzes to reinforce your understanding. 
    • Alternatively, attend a classroom training to prepare for the certification. There, you will get access to a real system to complete exercises on your own. See the training page for upcoming classroom sessions. 
  3. Get more hands-on experience 
    • Practice using SAP Integration Suite in different scenarios. For example, you can complete missions in the discovery center.   
    • Experiment with SAP Integration Suite features beyond the course exercises to deepen your understanding. 
  4. Create a study plan 
    • Set a realistic study schedule. Spread your learning over a few weeks rather than cramming at the last minute. 
  5. Take a Practice Test  
    • Use the sample questions provided by SAP to get a feel for the exam format and question style. 
  6. Rest well before the exam 
    • Avoid last-minute cramming. It’s better to be well-rested and focused. 
  7. Read Questions Carefully During the Exam 
    • Pay attention to keywords like "best," "most effective," or "first step." 
    • Eliminate obviously wrong answers before choosing the best one. 
    • If unsure, mark the question for review and return to it later. 

 

Share Your Certification Journey and Help Others Succeed 

Earning your SAP Integration Suite certification is a great achievement, and your experience can help others on the same path. Share your journey in the Integration Group by posting about your study strategies, favorite resources, and exam tips. Whether it’s a learning method that worked well for you or a resource you found particularly useful, your insights could make a big difference for those preparing for the exam.

entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): Architecture, Deployment, and Seamless Connectivity
entry.content:
In today’s digital landscape, businesses rely on multiple interconnected systems to manage operations, from finance and supply chain to customer relationship management. However, maintaining consistent and accurate master data across these systems can be challenging. SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) addresses this challenge by providing a unified framework for seamless data synchronization across SAP and non-SAP applications. By leveraging MDI, organizations can ensure data consistency, improve efficiency, and reduce integration complexities.

What Is SAP Master Data Integration (MDI)?

In the era of the Intelligent Enterprise, seamless data connectivity is essential for ensuring operational efficiency. SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) is a powerful, multi-tenant cloud service designed to act as a central hub for managing and synchronizing master data across various applications.

By integrating with SAP MDI, applications can maintain consistency by syncing their local master data repositories with a centralized master data database. Typically, each enterprise landscape is assigned a single MDI tenant, ensuring a unified and consistent view of master data across all connected systems.

Unlike traditional master data management solutions, SAP MDI focuses exclusively on integration. It facilitates the replication of master data records, allowing applications to perform initial data loads and continuously stay synchronized with the central database. Administrators have full control over data synchronization, enabling them to define integration rules, monitor replication processes, and ensure compliance with data protection and privacy regulations.

With SAP Master Data Integration, businesses can eliminate data silos, improve data accuracy, and create a streamlined digital ecosystem where applications communicate effortlessly.

Current Architecture

* Does not cause any additional costs for customers having a BTP Global Account integrating SAP-branded cloud solutions, ready-to-use integration, standard for SAP-branded cloud applications

** Utilize SAP Integration Suite when ready-to-use integration is not available
*** Current integration of CX solutions mostly via SAP Integration Suite (direct integration on roadmap)
 

SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) is designed to act as a central hub for seamless master data synchronization across various enterprise applications. Its architecture ensures that both SAP and non-SAP systems can efficiently exchange master data while maintaining consistency across the entire IT landscape.

Direct Integration with SAP Cloud Applications

MDI directly integrates with several SAP Cloud applications using pre-built SAP MDI Adapters. These adapters enable a smooth and standardized data flow between MDI and the following SAP solutions:

  • SAP Field Service Management (FSM)
  • SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP S/4HANA (Public & Private Cloud)
  • SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) Cloud
  • SAP Fieldglass
  • SAP Ariba
  • SAP Customer Experience (CX)

Since these applications are built to work with SAP MDI, they can directly exchange master data without requiring additional middleware.

Integration with Non-SAP Applications and SAP ECC Systems

For legacy SAP ECC systems and non-SAP applications, direct connectivity to MDI is not available. Instead, SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) acts as a middleware, facilitating communication between these systems and MDI. SAP CPI includes an MDI Adapter, which enables:

  • Secure and scalable integration of ECC and third-party applications with MDI.
  • Transformation and enrichment of master data before synchronization.
  • A flexible approach to integrate on-premise and hybrid cloud landscapes.

This hybrid architecture ensures that both modern cloud-based applications and traditional on-premise systems can participate in a unified master data strategy, reducing data silos and improving consistency across the enterprise.
Feature Scope Description can be found here: MDI Feature Scope 
Information on Pricing can be found here: MDI Service Pricing
System Limitations can be found here: MDI System Limitations 
More Feature info can be found here: MDI Features 

What is SAP One Domain Model?

SAP One Domain Model is a standardized, common model for business objects across various SAP solutions. By aligning master data structures across SAP applications, ODM facilitates deep, out-of-the-box integration, simplified extensions, and consistent APIs for the SAP Intelligent Enterprise.

Key Features of SAP One Domain Model

✅ Unified Data Structure: Provides a harmonized representation of business objects, ensuring consistency across different SAP applications.
✅ Standardized Integration: Enables seamless data exchange between applications like S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, Ariba, Fieldglass, and Customer Experience solutions.
✅ Core Data Services (CDS) Based Definitions: The model definitions are written in Core Data Services (CDS), forming the foundation for a consistent data view across hybrid landscapes.
✅ Foundation for Integration & Analytics: Aligns configurations, master data, and transactional data, enabling robust integration, extension, and analytics scenarios.

By adopting SAP One Domain Model, organizations can eliminate data inconsistencies, streamline integration efforts, and create a cohesive digital enterprise where applications interact seamlessly.

All supported Integration Models can be found here:
Integration Models 

Getting Started with SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): A Simple Guide

SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) helps businesses ensure seamless master data synchronization across multiple applications. While the technical implementation requires expertise, understanding the initial setup helps organizations plan and prepare for MDI adoption.

Pre-requisites

Before setting up MDI, the following are required:
✅ SAP BTP Global Account – This is the foundation for accessing SAP cloud services.
✅ SAP BTP Sub-account – A sub-account in the appropriate region where MDI is available:

  • Europe (Frankfurt) – EU10, EU11
  • US East (Virginia) – US10
  • Australia (Sydney) – AP10
  • Singapore – AP11
  • China – CN40
    ✅ Spaces in Sub-account – Organizational units where services like MDI are deployed.

Initial Setup Steps

1️⃣ Create a Tenant

  • Each sub-account can have one MDI tenant.
  • A tenant is created when you subscribe to the SAP Master Data Integration Tenant application.
  • Each service instance within a sub-account connects to a client (e.g., S/4HANA, SuccessFactors).
  • Best Practice:
    • For production, create one MDI tenant to ensure data consistency.
    • For a three-system landscape (Development, Test, Production), use three separate tenants to prevent unintended data sharing.

2️⃣ Create a Service Instance

  • For every application you connect, a dedicated service instance must be created from the SAP BTP marketplace.
  • After creating a service instance, set up a service binding to generate credentials for connectivity.
  • You can generate multiple credentials for an application by creating additional service bindings.

3️⃣ Configure the Client

  • Define configuration details for each connected application.
  • Key attributes include:
    ✅ Business System ID
    ✅ Write Permissions
    ✅ Global Tenant ID
    ✅ logSys (Logical System)

4️⃣ Generate Service Keys

  • After configuring the service instance, generate a service key.
  • The service key is needed for authentication and establishing connectivity between SAP MDI and applications like S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, or Ariba.

5️⃣ Configure Master Data Orchestration/Business Data Orchestration

  • Use Business Data Orchestration to manage master data replication.
  • This allows you to:
    ✅ Define distribution models for data replication.
    ✅ Add extension fields to customize data attributes.
    ✅ Monitor the distribution status of master data.

Please note, additional steps would be required to SOAP Applications, like additional distribution models in MDO, creating and configuring Destinations. This would be required for objects like Business Partners.
Also for connecting S/4HANA Cloud or Cloud Applications Based on the SAP BTP ABAP environment, we would require to create communication arrangements (SAP_COM_0659) , (SAP_COM_0594) , Create destinations for MDO and Setup Distribution Models.

What’s Next?

Once MDI is set up, your applications can start synchronizing master data efficiently. To ensure smooth operations, businesses should work closely with their IT teams or SAP partners for technical implementation, monitoring, and optimization.

entry.title: New SAP LeanIX adapter for SAP Integration Suite is available!
entry.content:
Motivation

To simplify the integration with SAP LeanIX, we created an Standard adapter for SAP Integration Suite.

The current features are:

  • the adapter can use the GraphQL and REST API endpoints of SAP LeanIX
  • read data from SAP LeanIX workspaces for further processing in Integration Suite
  • Update data in SAP LeanIX with an easy-to-use UI in the adapter config

Some benefits for customer could be:

  • Integrate SAP LeanIX more seamlessly with other SAP and Non-SAP solutions
  • Give also Low- and NoCode developer an easy way to get data in and out of SAP LeanIX
  • Easily use and adapt our standard integration scenarios through SAP standard content

Architecture overview

The adapter is available via SAP Business Accelerator Hub. There is no option to use it as sender adapter (see next chapter), but as receiver adapter for GraphQL and REST interface. It also covers the login to SAP LeanIX in an easy way. You can use predefined REST or GraphQL queries directly via the adapter config or build you custom GraphQL statements.  

Sender Scenario

To send data from SAP LeanIX to another system, you could use WebHooks: How that could be done, is described here. To use this data in SAP Integration Suite, you can create an Integration Flow with a HTTP Sender adapter. For authorization purpose, we have a option for basic auth and OAuth2 in SAP LeanIX for WebHooks.

 

Features

Simple Integration Flow

GraphQL Protocol

  • Query and manipulate Fact Sheet via GraphQL
  • Pass created queries or use adapter feature to build your query
  • Full coverage of LeanIX GraphQL API
  • Security Handling for connecting to LeanIX

REST Protocol

  • Build REST queries for LeanIX a No-Code way
  • Full coverage of LeanIX REST API with dependencies and parameter
  • Security Handling for connecting to SAP LeanIX

Outlook

With the release of the SAP LeanIX adapter, we delivered some basic features to make integrations easier for developers. What do you think, what could be helpful? What would be scenarios, you would like to implement in SAP Integration Suite?

Here are some ideas, where I would like to get feedback from you, if that would be helpful?

For the SAP LeanIX adapter:

  • Add transactional logic
  • Enable extended exception handling
  • Flexible GraphQL query builder
  • Mass operations
  • better Support for custom Fact Sheets

For potential Integration Content packages:

  • Integration with more SAP Cloud Solutions?
  • Custom Integrations with SAP Signavio and SAP CALM?
  • Custom Integrations with other CMDB and project management solutions etc.?

entry.title: SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM - Token Based Authentication (Avoid BasicAuth protocol)
entry.content:
Token-based authentication is essential for several reasons, especially in today's technology with SAP BTP Integrations, SAP Build for web and mobile applications . Here are some key benefits:

  1. Security: Tokens are more secure than traditional session-based authentication. They are typically short-lived and can be easily revoked if compromised. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access.

  2. Scalability: Token-based authentication is stateless, meaning the server does not need to store session information. This makes it easier to scale applications horizontally, as each request is self-contained.

  3. Flexibility: Tokens can be used across different domains and services, enabling single sign-on (SSO) and integration with third-party services. This is particularly useful in microservices architectures.

  4. Performance: Since tokens are self-contained and do not require server-side session storage, they can improve the performance of your application by reducing the load on the server.

  5. User Experience: Tokens can be stored on the client side (e.g., in local storage or cookies), allowing users to remain authenticated across multiple sessions and devices without needing to log in repeatedly.

  6. SAP Build Apps, Side by Side Extensions and API Integration: Token-based authentication is well-suited for various business use cases for designing extensions for web, mobile applications and APIs, where maintaining server-side sessions is impractical. Tokens can be easily included in HTTP headers for secure communication

Note : SSC V2 Currently only REST is supported.  No Odata APIs are existed today

SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 - API Documentation 

Below template is ready usable for Visual Studio Code with Rest Client Extension enabled. Just copy and create as file as api.http

 = https://XXXXXX.de1.demo.crm.cloud.sap
@user = XXXXXXXXX
@password = XXXXXXXXXX



###
#  login
GET {{url}}/sap/c4c/api/v1/iam-service/token
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Basic {{user}}:{{password}}

@accessToken = {{login.response.body.value.access_token}}

###
GET {{url}}/auth/token?grant_type=refresh_token
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{accessToken}}


###
GET {{url}}/sap/c4c/api/v1/iam-service/users?$top=15&$skip=0
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{accessToken}}

Kindly share the blog to all your colleagues who can get benefited.

entry.title: Enable SAP Developer Hub as central Event Catalog
entry.content:
Introduction

In a world where event-driven architectures (EDA) are gaining traction, enterprises need a central and consistent way to document, discover, and consume events. SAP is addressing this need with an exciting roadmap initiative: enabling the SAP Developer Hub to act as a central Event Catalog.

This blog will walk you through the motivation behind this feature, how it fits into SAP’s broader strategy, and what steps you can take to prepare. We'll also include some insights into the current capabilities and what’s coming next.

 

Why a Central Event Catalog Matters

Managing asynchronous APIs and events across hybrid landscapes can quickly become complex. Having a unified developer experience—where both REST APIs and events are discoverable in one place—simplifies onboarding and integration across teams.

This aligns perfectly with SAP’s vision for a unified API consumption layer, with the SAP Developer Hub playing a central role.

Roadmap Highlights

SAP has identified several key innovations in this space, as published in the SAP Roadmap Explorer. Here are some of the most relevant items:

✅Developer Hub: Event Catalog - Basic Discovery

Link to roadmap item

SAP has enabled basic discovery of events directly via the Developer Hub. This allows developers to search, browse, and inspect event metadata just like they would with REST APIs.

✅ Expose Event Definitions via API Business Hub

Link to roadmap item

This has enabled event definitions available in a reusable and standardized format, ensuring that producers and consumers can align on payload structures, topics, and semantics.

🔜Enhanced Event Metadata

Link to roadmap item

SAP plans to enhance event metadata support, offering more insights into event types, versions, and schemas. This will enrich the Event Catalog experience and further empower developers working in event-driven scenarios.

How does it look like: Event Catalog in Developer Hub

Let's do it based on one example Event from SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh to Developer Hub.

Download AsyncAPI

In SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh navigate to Designer > API Product > Event > Download AsyncAPI

Create Event Product 

In SAP Developer Hub navigate to Admin Center > Content > Products > Add Event > Publish

Discovery SAP Events from SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh in Developer Hub

In SAP Developer search/navigate to your Event

Conclusion

The introduction of an Event Catalog in the Developer Hub is a major step forward in enabling event-driven, loosely coupled architectures in the SAP ecosystem.

If you're working with events today—or plan to—this is the right time to explore the feature, start aligning your assets, and get ready to expose your events to the wider enterprise.

🔗Don't forget to check the roadmap links above for the latest delivery timelines and feature details.

entry.title: How to migrate Boomi Integrations to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
1. Purpose of the document

This blog provides a comprehensive guide on migrating SAP SuccessFactors HCM integrations from Boomi to SAP Integration Suite (SAP IS), highlighting its strategic advantages, including prepackaged integrations, Tech Envo Accelerators, Migration Framework, Migration Process,  Design considerations, and hybrid deployment options. It covers SAP’s runtime environments, deployment models, and TechEnvo’s migration accelerators, ensuring a seamless migration. With TechEnvo’s expertise and adherence to SAP best practices, organizations can modernize their integration landscape while ensuring scalability, consistency, and long-term success.

 

2. Why SAP SuccessFactors HCM customer needs to migrate from Boomi to SAP Integration Suite

  • Between 2013 and 2016, SAP SuccessFactors HCM customers used BOOMI as an integration platform to support data integration requirements in SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation, and many customers are still running on Boomi.
  • SAP Customers have significantly invested in SAP BTP and SAP Integration Suite in the last seven years as part of S4HANA transitions and Integration Modernization (moving from SAP PO to SAP IS). 
  • Customers are migrating interfaces from Boomi to the SAP Integration Suite, aligning with the SAP Integration strategy.
  • Maintaining multiple integration platforms adds a lot of Technical Debt, and SAP customers consolidate and move to one integration platform (SAP Integration Suite) 
  • SAP Integration Suite Capabilities on par with BOOMI

3. SAP Integration Suite Capabilities and Features

SAP Integration Suite (SAP IS) is the strategic integration platform for SAP customers, offering seamless connectivity with over 3,400 prebuilt integrations and 3,800+ APIs. It provides all the capabilities of Boomi and additional advantages such as prepackaged content covering most of the SAP Solutions Integrations, AI-driven integration, and enhanced security. 

SAP Integration Suite is a comprehensive set of tools and services that enable seamless integration across various SAP and third-party systems. It helps businesses connect, automate, and optimize their processes across cloud and on-premises environments. Here are some key features and components of the SAP Integration Suite:

3.1 Key Features:

  • Connectivity: Provides pre-built connectors and adapters for integrating various SAP and third-party applications, such as SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, and external applications like Salesforce and Microsoft Dynamics.
  • Integration Flows: Facilitates the orchestration of data between applications with customizable integration flows, enabling businesses to automate workflows and synchronize data.
  • API Management: Allows businesses to manage their APIs in a secure and scalable manner, with tools to create, expose, and govern APIs across multiple environments.
  • Data Transformation: Supports the transformation of data between different formats (e.g., XML, JSON) to ensure seamless communication between systems.
  • Monitoring and Analytics: Provides dashboards and monitoring tools for real-time visibility into integration processes and system health, allowing proactive management.
  • Cloud-Based: Being cloud-native, SAP Integration Suite provides flexibility and scalability to handle evolving integration needs.
  • Security: Offers robust security features, including authentication, authorization, encryption, and secure communication for data exchanges

3.2 SAP Integration Suite Core Components:

  1. SAP Cloud Integration (CPI): A cloud-based integration platform for connecting SAP and non-SAP applications. It allows seamless integration of cloud and on-premise systems.
  2. SAP API Management: A solution to design, publish, and monitor APIs, providing tools to securely expose and consume APIs.
  3. SAP Open Connectors: A collection of pre-built connectors to a variety of third-party applications and services.
  4. SAP Integration Advisor: A tool that automates the mapping and transformation of data across systems, helping streamline the integration process.
  5. SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP): While the Integration Suite is a part of BTP, it works closely with other BTP services like SAP HANA, SAP AI, and SAP analytics for a comprehensive digital transformation solution.

3.3 SAP Integration Suite Use Cases:

  • ERP Integration: Connect SAP SuccessFactors HCM and SAP S/4HANA with other enterprise systems, such as CRM, Payroll, and Time, Benefits..etc, to ensure a unified view of business operations.
  • Cloud and On-Premises Integration: Link cloud-based applications (e.g., SAP SuccessFactors HCM ) with on-premises systems (e.g., SAP ECC).
  • API-First Strategy: Enable businesses to expose services as APIs and integrate them with external systems for broader connectivity.
  • Data Synchronization: Automatically sync data between systems, ensuring consistency and eliminating manual data entry errors.

3.4 SAP Integration Suite Benefits:

  • Faster Time-to-Value: Pre-built integrations and connectors reduce implementation time.
  • Scalability: Easily scale integration scenarios as your business grows and systems evolve.
  • Flexibility: The suite supports various integration scenarios, from simple point-to-point integrations to complex, multi-cloud architectures.
  • Cost Efficiency: Reduces integration complexity and costs by leveraging a unified platform for all integration needs.

In summary, SAP Integration Suite enables organizations to drive digital transformation by ensuring seamless integration across their entire IT landscape, whether using SAP or third-party applications.

 

4.Boomi to SAP Integration Suite Migration – Tech Envo Framework 

We have worked on multiple Boomi to SAP Integration Suite migration projects and developed a framework and strategy for successful migrations.

 

4.1 Scope of Boomi Integrations to be migrated to SAP Integration Suite:

This is the first step in the migration process: identifying the number of integrations currently running in the Boomi Production Atom environment and ensuring the scope is determined. 

4.2 Document pain points and current environment: 

Talk to the business and technical team supporting the integrations in the BOOMI environment and get a list of pain points and challenges. This is a critical step, and addressing these issues in the SAP Integration Suite after migration is necessary.

Common pain points : 

  1. Poor Integration design 
  2. Poor Integration coding standards 
  3. Not implementing prepackaged integrations
  4. Customizing prepackaged integrations 
  5. Heavy Groovy scripting
  6. Lack of better error handling mechanisms
  7. Lack of documentation
  8. Not using the correct SAP SuccessFactors APIs
  9. Delta Logic is missing 
  10. No encryption
  11. Authentication type issues 
  12. Tightly coupled interfaces - not easy to make updates.

4.3 Identify Integration Patterns: 

Identity integration patterns like Synchronous, Asynchronous, cloud-to-cloud, cloud-to-on-premises, On-premise—on-premise Integration, Scheduled, Real-Time, Type of Systems involved, etc., and create an SAP Integration Suite Integration patterns covering all scenarios. 

  • Synchronous Integration – Real-time data exchange with immediate response—API-to-API communication between SAP SuccessFactors and another system.


                   Fig: Payments canada to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Master Data Sync Integration

Fig: High Resolution flow of Payments canada to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Master Data Sync

  • Asynchronous Integration – Data is sent without waiting for an immediate response.Sending employee updates from SAP SuccessFactors to External Applications.

Fig: Integration Flow of SAP SFEC to Metlife Employee Data Sync.

Fig:  High Resolution flow of SAP SFEC to Metlife Employee Data Sync Integration.

  • Cloud-to-Cloud Integration – Data exchange between two cloud applications.Syncing data between SAP SuccessFactors and another cloud-based system(ServiceNow,Okta, Workday,SAP Concur, SAP Fieldglass, S4HANA Cloud.etc)

Fig: Integration Flow of SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding to OKTA Data Sync Integration

Fig: High Resolution Flowof SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding to OKTA Data Sync Integration

  • Cloud-to-On-Premises Integration – Communication between a cloud-based system and an on-premises system.Triggering updates in an on-premises system from a cloud-based application(S4 HANA OP, SAP ECC, Data Lake OP, SFTP OP).

Fig: Integration Flow of SAP SFEC to ShareWorks Employee Data Sync

Fig: High Resolution Flow of SAP SFEC to ShareWorks Employee Data Sync

  • On-Premises to On-Premises Integration – Data exchange between two on-premises systems.Sending employee updates from SAP SuccessFactors to External Applications.

Fig:  Integration Flow of SAP S4HANA or SAP ECC to BankMaster Data Replication

Fig: High Resolution Flow of SAP S4HANA or SAP ECC to BankMaster Data Replication

  • Scheduled Integration – Batch processing executed at defined intervals.Daily batch transfer of employee records from SAP SuccessFactors.

Fig: Integration Flow of SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding to Qualtrics Data Sync 

Fig: High Resolution flow of SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding to Qualtrics Data Sync 

  • Real-Time Integration – Event-driven or API-based real-time integration.Triggering real-time updates in one system based on events in another.
  • Employee Demographic Data Outbound Integrations

Fig: Active directory(Outbound) to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Demographic Data Sync

  • Employee Data Update Inbound Integrations

Fig: Integration Flow of Active directory(Inbound) to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Demographic Data Sync

Fig: High Resolution Flow Active directory(Inbound) to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Demographic Data Sync

4.4 Create Migration Strategy 

  • Create a detailed strategy covering all aspects of migration:
  1. Deployment Approach and Timelines
  2. Prioritization of interfaces
  3. Technical Architecture
  4. Documenting best practices 

4.5 Map Boomi capabilities with SAP Integration Suite

Identify capabilities used in BOOMI and map which capabilities you need to use in IS. This will give a clear picture of gaps in capabilities and how they can be solved, such as connectors used, API management, Scripting, security, Retry mechanism, error logging capabilities, etc. 

Tech Envo's best practices always include using standard capabilities offered by the SAP integration suite and implementation prepacked integration before building custom integrations.  

4.6 Create Technical Architecture / Design and Development standards

Creating a technical design for each interface is critical. The technical design can be reused depending on the integration type and pattern. Create detailed technical design standards and a framework for the topics below. 

  • Development standards
  • Naming conventions
  • Reusable framework / a common framework (reuse of scripts, security materials, etc)
  • Documentation standards and deliverables
  • Interface development life cycle
  • Interface testing 
  • API best practices 

4.7 Integration Build and Testing

Ensure that the integration consultant working on the integration build has the expertise below. This will help build high-quality integrations. 

  • A clear understanding of SAP SuccessFactors HCM APIs 
  • Excellent hands-on experience in the SAP Integration suite 
  • Experience in Integration build for SAP SuccessFactors HCM
  • Able to understand BOOMI integration code (Boomi platform)

Create a detailed development process for all integrations, align on the development approach, and implement leading practices. This will ensure consultants working on the project follow the same standards and help support the interfaces better.

For example, if you are building delta logic for SAP SuccessFactors HCM data extract, ensure this logic can be reusable across interfaces. Usually, we create a reusable Groovy script. Maintaining the code would be less effort if everyone used the same approach.

4.8 Integrations Testing and comparing BOOMI/SAP Integration Suite Outputs. 

Integration testing is a critical phase of the project. Ensure you document all test cases, check if any are available from the Boomi project, and enhance the same with additional cases. Run the integration in the Boomi environment and SAP Integration suite and compare data. If data matches both platforms, logic integration in SAP integration suits and covers all requirements but follows this process for all scenarios. 

4.9 Deployment in SAP Integration Suite Production 

Once the business approves the integration, plan the deployment in the SAP Integration Suite production environment and schedule as required. Un-deploy or stop the Boomi schedule for the interfaces deployed in the SAP IS prod environment. 

5. Boomi to SAP Cloud Integration - Migration High-Level Decision Flow to determine Integration approach 

The primary goal of the below decision is to leverage prepackaged integrations as much as possible before building a custom integration solution. This approach aligns with the recommendation of SAP's leading practices and SAP clean core principles.

 

 

6. Tech Envo Migration Accelerators

TechEnvo Migration Accelerators include 74+ prepackaged integrations and templates for SAP SuccessFactors HXM in SAP Integration Suite, reusable Framework, and an advanced error-handling framework. Our team is experts in Boomi, SAP Integration Suite, and SAP SuccessFactors HCM solutions, with deep knowledge of SAP SuccessFactors APIs and best practices. With 700+ integrations built using SAP Integration Suite and Boomi, we bring extensive migration experience, ensuring a seamless transition from Boomi to SAP Integration Suite. Our certified professionals have successfully executed multiple Boomi-to-SAP IS migration projects, leveraging industry-leading methodologies.

 

Interface ID

Target System
