7. Tech Envo Migration Framework  – SAP SuccessFactors Integration Approach

As part of the migration, 

We develop high-quality integrations in SAP Integration Suite, utilizing its full capabilities to ensure optimal performance. Our approach prioritizes leveraging pre-delivered features with minimal customization by using standard mapping functions and predefined process steps offered by SAP Integration Suite. We also enforce industry-leading development standards aligned with SAP best practices and organizations' leading practices, ensuring consistency, maintainability, and scalability across all integrations.

 

  1. We implement direct API-based Direct integrations if the vendor has built integration and is available in the SAP App Center (e.g., Hire Right, Nakisa, JDMS, SailPoint, Omada IDM, Okta, etc.). Direct integrations avoid the middleware layer and reduce development and support costs.
  2. We implement prepackaged integrations developed by SAP, Tech Envo, or Vendor to reduce development effort and customization.
  3.  We use SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center (IC) if the Integration Center integrations require less effort to build and maintain.
  4. We have built reusable integration templates, which we can use if we need to develop a custom integration. 

 

8. SAP Integration Suite Technical Landscape, Cloud Foundry Environment

  • Cloud Foundry: The Cloud Foundry environment in SAP BTP is an open-source application runtime supporting Java, Node.js, and other languages, ideal for extending SAP products, integrating applications, and building enterprise solutions using SAP-hosted APIs. 
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/technical-landscape-cloud-foundry-environment 

 

9. Deployment Environments of SAP Integration Suite

  • Cloud Integration Runtime: A cloud-based service in SAP Integration Suite, enabling seamless data exchange between cloud and on-premise applications like Boomi Cloud  Atoms.
  • Edge Integration Cell: A hybrid integration runtime in SAP Integration Suite that allows designing in the cloud while running integrations on-premise, equivalent to Boomi On-Premise Atom
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/setting-up-and-managing-edge-integration-cell 
  • Hybrid Deployment Option: Customer can use both Cloud Integration Runtime and Edge Integration Cell - Hybrid deployment option. 

 

10. SFEC to SAP ERP/S4HANA Integrations Migration Approach

We migrate Boomi legacy SAP S4 HANA, SAP ERP HCM, SAP ECC integrations to the BIB Replication Framework for seamless. Employee and Organizational Data replication. Our expertise includes implementing BIB-based integrations for multiple customers, including SAP S/4HANA environments. We have developed accelerators to handle complex replication scenarios, such as dynamic actions, pensioners’ data replication, concurrent employment, and global assignments, ensuring a robust and efficient migration process and no impact to payroll during migration.

 

Migration Key Considerations

1.Connectivity

  • The IP address changes for  Boomi data center (Atoms) and SAP IS are different, so the firewall ports and network config must be updated with new IP range details during migration.
  • Server and Client certificates in the on-premise ERP system must also be updated during migration.
  • Any custom integrations built using SuccessFactors SMTP server for sending emails must be changed to a publicly available SMTP server, as SuccessFactors does not allow external access to its SMTP server.
  • Any locally installed atom needs to be changed to use SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)/Edge Integration. SAP Cloud Connector connects on-premise systems with SAP IS without opening tunnels.

2.Instance Strategy:

  • Depending on the license model, SAP provides two tenants (Test and Production) by default, but we recommend using a three-tier architecture.
  • Multi-tier architecture requires an additional SAP IS tenant, which may involve extra costs.

 

3.Cloud to On-Premise Connectivity

  • On-premise connections via Boomi Local Atom need migration to SAP Cloud Connector or Edge Integration Cell.
  • Proxy tools used in Boomi can still be leveraged in SAP Cloud Integration.

 

4.Interface Mapping: Existing interfaces need to be evaluated based on the following 4 buckets:

  1. Boomi Pre-Packaged to SAP IS Pre-Packaged /Direct API-based integration 
  2. Boomi custom integration to SAP IS a Pre-Packaged integration 
  3. Boomi Custom Integration to SF Integration Center Integrations
  4. Custom Boomi to Custom SAP Integration Suite 

5.Interface Prioritization

  1. Prioritize high-risk integrations such as Payroll, Time, and Benefits 
  2. Ensure SAP IS generates output with the same logic as Boomi.
  3. Validate output files between Boomi and SAP IS to streamline testing.

entry.title: Informatica Intelligent Data Management Cloud & BTP-IS Integration
entry.content:
Intelligent Data Management Cloud (IDMC) provides a robust cloud data integration architecture designed for scalability and flexibility. At its core is the Informatica Cloud Platform, featuring a user-friendly interface and a drag-and-drop Cloud Designer for creating integration mappings.

 

1. MDM Inbound Integration to CPI

The main inbound flow into Informatica IDMC is called reconciliation. Scope of MDM Inbound integration is to extract or receive data from source system and load it into MDM. This will be either by batch or near real time. CDI mapping should be established for batch integration. CAI process combined with OOTB MDM API to be used for near real time integration.

2. MDM Outbound Integration to CPI

The main outbound flow from IDMC is called Distribution, Once the master record is established for a
given entity, IDMC then distribute the mater record data to other applications or databases.

Scope of outbound integration is to make the master data available to downstream systems.

MDM will publish outbound payloads to an Azure Service Bus queue from where SAP BTP will consume the payload and act as a middleware to distribute master data to downstream systems. Master data along with the “distribution logic” will get pushed from MDM outbound layer to Azure Service Bus, so it can be distributed by BTP to downstream application

Purpose of each component and intermediate jobs are described in below diagram-

Distribution Approaches Considered:

A. Distribution Approach in BTP_IS

B. S/4 Data Replication Framework (DRF)

C. Distribution of MDM data in MDMHUB

Comparison of Approaches

Exception Handling in CPI & MDM HUB

The middleware layer (BTP_IS) plays a critical role in delivering master data to the target systems. During this process, exceptions can occur primarily due to:
    • Mapping or data validation failures within the middleware
    • Communication issues while connecting to the destination system

In the event of such failures, BTP_IS prepares a detailed error feedback, including the complete payload, the target system that failed, and specific exception information. To manage these failures effectively, a dedicated exception queue is maintained at MDM, which is responsible for collecting and tracking all failed messages.
The reprocessing of failed records from this queue is governed by the MDM team, ensuring that error handling aligns with data governance policies.

Additionally, for failures that occur within SAP S/4HANA, a separate interface sends acknowledgment
notifications back to MDM via the ALEAUD IDoc.

#IDMC #MDMHUB #CPI #MasterData #Integration#Middleware #BTP #IntegrationSuit

entry.title: Integration of Custom Code Migration app to ERP system using Cloud Integration Automation Service
entry.content:
In recent years, SAP customers have extensively expanded and adjusted their SAP solutions. Some SAP ERP systems now contain several million lines of custom code. When converting to SAP S/4HANA, customers are seeking to reuse their existing custom code.

If you are planning for system conversion to SAP S/4HANA and thinking about custom code adoption, integrating Custom Code Migration app to your on prem ERP system is the way forward.

But how about making the whole integration process between Custom Code Migration app and ERP system simpler and faster.

Cloud Integration Automation service is a free of cost standard integration service available in SAP BTP and can be leveraged for integrating Custom Code Migration app to the on prem ERP system. The service provides guided workflows for simpler and faster integration eliminating most of the manual steps.

Prerequisite

You need:

    • An SAP Cloud Platform Cloud Foundry (BTP) account in one of the Cloud Integration Automation service supported data centers or an SAP Cloud Integration account
    • System instances of licensed SAP cloud products that are in scope of the integration scenarios

How to start your integration with Cloud Integration Automation service:

    • Activate your Cloud Integration Automation service in the Service Marketplace of your SAP BTP Cockpit

Cloud Integration Automation service subscription: blog

Plan for Integration

Once you have the subscription, you can start planning for the integration by clicking on the tile Plan for Integration as highlighted below. ￼

Find the Custom Code Migration app from the list of integration scenarios supported by Cloud Integration Automation service.

In the subsequent Fiori screen, you will find more details about the Custom Code Migration app such as

  • Description
  • Scenario Entities
  • Scenario Tasks

Then, click on Select Systems as highlighted in the above screenshot.

The service displays all the components which are required for the integration between Custom Code Migration app and ERP system.

On selection of these components, the service also displays the tenants which are there for this component in your landscape.

For Custom Code Migration app, the different components are

  • SAP ERP
  • SAP BTP Global Account
  • Cloud Connector

Select the ERP system from the system landscape.

Then click on SAP BTP Global Account and select the global account where you would like to set up the Custom Code Migration app.

Then, click on Cloud Connector and select the appropriate Cloud Connector.

After selecting the cloud connector click on Generate workflow highlighted in the above screen.

Check the detail and Click on Generate.

A guided workflow will be generated with all the configuration steps for Custom Code Migration app integration with the ERP system.

Inbox

You can open the generated workflow in the My Inbox.

In the subsequent screen check / provide the system details.

You have the possibility to add any missing information manually and Confirm Systems.

You can assign the roles for the different components which are

  • SAP ERP Administrator
  • SAP BTP Global Account Administrator
  • Cloud Connector Administrator

Click on Confirm Role Assignment and subsequently Confirm Scope Selection as highlighted in the below screen.

Once you confirm the scope, you will be able to see number of tasks that is needed for integration of Custom Code Migration app to the ERP system. Not only the tasks, but the service also provides information, images, deep links and support information for the respective components for simpler and faster integration.

Some of the tasks, example Create BTP Subaccount is all most fully automated, where the user needs to provide few parameters such as Subaccount Region, Subaccount Display Name, Subaccount Subdomain etc. and click on the Execute Task button as highlighted in the below screenshot to complete an integration task.

Users can follow the instructions for all the tasks and complete the tasks by clicking on the Task Completed button.

 

Scenario Monitoring

You can also monitor the progress of the tasks in the Scenario Monitoring.

It displays the completed and in progress tasks.

 

Note: It is worth to mention that to complete the end-to-end integration of the Custom Code Migration app, the users need to complete all the tasks.

As a task orchestration tool Cloud Integration Automation service can truly accelerates the whole integration process by providing partially automated, role-based workflows, including system landscape information and integrated parameter management.

entry.title: New SAP Architecture Center: Foundation for Enterprise Architecture & Architects
entry.content:
The new Introduction from SAP, the  SAP Architecture Center is among one of the best addition to SAP's resources, making a centralized hub for SAP solution reference architectures. Through this addition, businesses can adopt SAP Solutions in a more effective manner, extracting valuable business insights from organizational data.

 

Key Features of the SAP Architecture Center

  • Comprehensive Reference Architectures: The Architecture Center provides a wide range of reference solution architectures, covering multiple business needs though technological domains and design patterns.
  • Technology Domains: It caters various domains which include Automation, Artificial Intelligence, Application Development, Enterprise Integration, Governance and Security.
  • Technology Partners: SAP Architecture Center includes architecture involving major technology players like GCP, Microsoft Azure, AWS etc.
  • Interactive Exploration Tools: SAP Architecture Center users will be able to navigate the architecture through using tools like Overview, Architecture Explorer, Card-Style, and Navigator Style Overview
  • Community Engagement: For community interaction, there is a dedicated section, encouraging collaboration and knowledge sharing among the SAP professionals.

 

SAP Viewpoints

 

Architecture Explorer:

Through the architecture explorer you navigate through the Technology Domains like integrations, AI, App Development & more and Technology Partners like AWS, Azure and GCP, discovering solution blueprints based on your specific requirement like you are  planning an AI Driven use case on Azure or exploring data Architecture AWS, the Architecture Center guides through the most inline architecture assets with ease.

 

Technology Domains:

  • Application Development & Automation: Build and extend SAP applications using low-code tools, CAP, and event-driven architectures.

  • Artificial Intelligence: Integrate AI and machine learning into business processes with SAP AI Core and Launchpad.

  • Data & Analytics: Design unified data strategies with SAP Datasphere, BW/4HANA, and Analytics Cloud.

  • Integration: Enable secure and scalable integration across cloud and on-premise systems using SAP Integration Suite.

  • Operations & Security: Implement best practices for system security, observability, DevOps, and compliance.

 

Technology Domains:

The SAP Architecture Center focuses on the reference architectures across leading hyperscalers

  • Microsoft Azure
  • AWS
  • GCP

Even if you are using GCP for orchestrating analytics workloads, running BTP services on Azure or data Pipelines on AWS. The SAP Architecture center provides architectures patterns for each environment.

 

Reference Architectures:

SAP Architecture Center contains a rich repository of reference Architectures aligned with the recommended practices, well structured and reusable blueprints that elaborates how SAP Solutions are developed, integrated, deployed and scaled real world Enterprise Scenarios. Reference Architectures within the SAP Architecture Center is formulated in key sections, enriching the overall architecture in a more organized and easy to understand way. 


Conclusion:

Looking ahead, SAP Architecture Center will play a vital role driving standardized and future scoped solutions. As all the technologies are going through a continuous evolving process and towards a more modular, cloud native and AI Integrated solutions, and SAP heading towards the same,  many more things would be part of the SAP Architecture Center in the coming days which will accelerate digital transformations, ensuring architectural consistency. By adopting these reference architectures, your organization can future proof their Digital Transformation and IT Strategy with reduced complexity.

entry.title: New Integration Content for Coupa to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence Now Available
entry.content:
We’re excited to announce that new integration content for Coupa to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence is now available, offering organizations an enhanced capability to analyze their end-to-end procurement processes. This valuable integration is accessible free of charge on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, empowering businesses to make data-driven decisions with greater precision and efficiency.

Streamline Your Procurement Analysis

Procurement processes are complex, involving numerous stakeholders and steps that can create inefficiencies and gaps if not closely monitored. By leveraging the new integration content for Coupa and SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, you can gain comprehensive insights into your procurement workflows. This integration helps you visualize, analyze, and optimize the entire procurement process from purchase requisition to payment, ensuring greater transparency and continuous improvement.

How to Access the Integration Content

Accessing this powerful integration is straightforward. To get started:

Log in to the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

 

Navigate to the “Explore” tab and search for “SAP Signavio”.

 

Locate the new integration content for Coupa.

 

View the integration package and dedicated integration flows.

 

The integration package includes dedicated integration flows that outline the relevant business objects and events extracted by default. This setup enables a quick start with the flexibility to adjust and extend the content to meet your specific business needs.

Key Benefits of the Integration

  • End-to-End Visibility: Gain a holistic view of your procurement operations, identifying bottlenecks and opportunities for optimization.

  • Customizable Data Extraction: The predefined business objects and events can be tailored to your organization’s unique requirements, offering adaptability for varied use cases.

  • Enhanced Decision-Making: With seamless data extraction from Coupa and integration into SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, organizations can make informed decisions based on accurate process execution data.

Share Your Feedback

We value your input and look forward to hearing your thoughts on this new integration package. Share your experiences and suggestions in the comments section below.

Start analyzing and optimizing your procurement processes today with the new Coupa to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence integration. Discover how this solution can transform your operations and drive better outcomes.

In case you have not seen it yet, also check out the integration content we have recently released for Salesforce (Blog post / Integration content) and Microsoft Dynamics CRM (Blog post / Integration content)

entry.title: From Basics to Confidence: Testing SAP BTP iFlows with Postman
entry.content:
After building my first iFlow in SAP BTP Integration Suite, I was excited to test it — but I wasn’t sure where to start. That’s when I discovered Postman, a simple tool for testing HTTP requests. In this blog, I’ll walk you through how I used Postman to test my iFlow, and what I learned along the way. 

🔄What I Built 

I created a Mail Adapter iFlow: 

  • Trigger: HTTP POST request 
  • Step: Content Modifier (formatting) 
  • Output: Mail Adapter (send a notification email) 

The goal? Trigger the iFlow from Postman and see the email arrive. 

 

🔧Step 1: Set Up the iFlow 

  • Navigate to Design Workspace

    • Go to Integration Suite → Design → Integration & APIs

  • Create a New Package

    • Click Create Package
    • Enter Name: Mail_Testing

  • Add an Artifact to the Package

    • Open the Mail_Testing package
    • Click Create → Integration Flow

  • Configure the iFlow

    • Name: Mail_Simple
    • Click Add and Open in Editor

Design and Deploy the Mail iFlow:

  1. Edit the iFlow

    • Click Edit in the iFlow editor

  2. Modify the Start Event

    • Delete the default Sender
    • Add a Timer from the Event section
    • Delete the Start element

  3. Configure the Timer

    • Open the Timer Scheduler
    • Keep the configuration basic (default settings)

  4. Add a Content Modifier

    • Drag and drop a Content Modifier into the flow
    • Configure Message Body:
      • Type: Constant
      • Value:
        Hi All,
This is for sample testing mail.
Thanks & Regards,

  5. Connect to Mail Receiver

    • Connect the End of the flow to a Receiver
    • Select Mail Adapter as the receiver type

  6. Configure Mail Adapter Connection

    • Address: smtp.gmail.com:587
    • Protection: Optional
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Authorization Code
    • Credential Name: IS_GMAIL

  7. Set Mail Processing Details

    • From: Sender's mail
    • To: Receiver's mail
    • Subject: Testing

  8. Save and Deploy

    • Click Save
    • Click Deploy to activate the iFlow

Step 2: Configure OAuth2 Authorization Code in SAP BTP Integration Suite

  1. Navigate to Security Material

    • Go to Integration Suite → Monitor → Integration & APIs → Security Material

  2. Create New OAuth2 Authorization Code

    • Click Create
    • Select OAuth2 Authorization Code as the type.

  3. Fill in Configuration Details

    • Name: IS_GMAIL
    • Description: Gmail configuration
    • Provider: Generic
    • Authorization URL: <authuri>?access_type=offline&prompt=consent
    • Token URL: <authuri>/token
    • Client ID: <clientid>
    • Client Secret: <clientsecret>
    • Send As: Basic Authentication Header
    • Username: "sender's mail id"
    • Scope: https://mail.google.com/

 

🔗Step 3: Get the Endpoint URL 
After deployment: 

  • Go to Monitor → Manage Integration Content 
    Under Monitor- Integrations and API, added a security material for OAuth Authorization.
  • Find your iFlow and copy the endpoint URL 

🧪 Step 4: Test in Postman 
In Postman: 

  • Method: POST 
  • URL: Paste your endpoint 
  • Authorization: Basic Auth 
  • Use your Integration Suite credentials 
  • Headers: 
  • Content-Type: application/json 
  • Body (raw, JSON): 

json 

{ 

  "name": "Pranjali", 

  "email": "abc@example.com", 

  "message": "Test from Postman!" 

} 

Click Send. 

📈Step 5: Check the Results 

In SAP BTP: 

  • Go to Monitor → Monitor Message Processing 
  • Look for your iFlow execution 
  • Open the message to see: 
  • Payload trace 
  • Adapter logs 
  • Success or error details 

  

🧠 Tips & Common Errors that you phase while deploying the iflow:

  

Error 

Cause 

Fix 

401 

Unauthorized Wrong credentials or missing role 

Ensure ESBMessaging.send role is assigned 

404 

Not Found Incorrect endpoint 

Verify path /triggerEmail matches exactly 

Empty or broken payload 

Incorrect headers 

Add Content-Type: application/json 

Mail not received 

Mail adapter config issue 

Double-check SMTP host, port, and credentials 

Flow doesn’t appear in monitor 

Wrong trigger format 

 Ensure JSON body is well-formed and matches iFlow expectations 

  

✅Final Thoughts 

Testing your iFlows doesn’t need to be hard. Postman made it quick and easy for me to validate my flow and debug it. If you’re just getting started with SAP BTP Integration Suite, I highly recommend trying this out with a simple HTTP-to-Mail flow.

entry.title: How to Get Started with SAP S/4HANA and Amazon Seller Central Integration
entry.content:
Integrating Amazon Seller Central with SAP S/4HANA can sound like a complex project. But if you’re an Amazon merchant already using SAP, connecting the two can significantly boost your operations. In this article, we’ll cover everything you need to know before jumping in—from Amazon’s merchant models and APIs to setting up your SAP system and choosing the right integration method.

Amazon Merchant Models: What You Need to Know

Amazon offers several models for merchants to sign up, and understanding which commercial agreement you fall under is crucial for exploring the available solutions.

  • Vendor Central – This is an invite-only model where Amazon acts as a B2B partner by issuing a purchase order. The merchant supplies the goods to Amazon at an agreed-upon price and invoices Amazon accordingly. Amazon then takes care of selling the products, generating a profit from the sale. In this arrangement, the merchant has no control over the listed price or the final customer transaction.

As this model is a special case and relatively easy to integrate, we will cover it in more detail in a separate blog post.

  • Seller Central – In this model, the seller lists products on Amazon and is responsible for setting the price, handling customer orders, and fulfilling them. There are two sub-models for Seller Central:
  • Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM) – The seller stores the products in their own warehouse. When Amazon orders are placed, the seller’s logistics team picks and ships the products directly to the customer.
  • Fulfilled by Amazon (FBA) – Amazon stores the products on behalf of the merchant, distributing the inventory across its fulfillment centers based on demand. In this case, the merchant is only responsible for sending inventory to Amazon’s warehouses and restocking as necessary.

In both sub-models, Amazon pays the merchant every two weeks based on the sales of goods, minus Amazon’s fees and charges. We’ll discuss these fees in more detail shortly.

Understanding Amazon’s Fees vs Charges

Fees are the portion of the sales transaction that Amazon takes, such as the commission. This commission is deducted directly from the merchant’s payout after a sale. It represents Amazon’s share for providing the platform and services to facilitate the transaction. Merchants need to account for these fees when calculating their profits.

Charges, on the other hand, are costs that the customer pays. These may include shipping fees, taxes, or other additional costs associated with the purchase. Unlike fees, which are deducted from the merchant’s payout, charges are directly paid by the customer at checkout. The merchant does not bear the responsibility for these costs. Instead, they are part of the overall price the customer agrees to pay.

It must be noted that these Fees / Charges need to be recorded when Orders flow into SAP. For this reason, each of the relevant Fees and Charge need to be mapped to condition type.

There are a lot of fees and charges associated with Amazon and may be all of them do not apply to your case. You can get an estimate of Amazon fees and charges out here.

As shown above it is good the store all the Amazon fees and charges in a custom table to be able to further solutionize the integration.

Master Data Setup in SAP for Amazon Integration

To be able to set Amazon process within Amazon, you need to ensure that founding pillars are in place. Here are the details.

  • Plant / Customer – In both FBM and FBA Scenarios, you would need to track inventory as well as accept orders from Amazon. You would need to create Amazon as a customer as well as plant within SAP system

     

     

  • Material – All the material relevant for Amazon business must have an ASIN (Amazon Standard Identification Number). These are required be maintained and link with material master relevant for Amazon business. The best way to do the same is to maintain these are customer material info records with respect to customer created in above step.

Extending your materials for the Amazon-specific plant ensures SAP recognizes the stock location used for Amazon orders.

Technical Structure: Understanding Amazon SP-API

The next step is to understand the Amazon API structure. I have worked with various integrations and can say that using these APIs requires moderate to advanced knowledge. This is because there are interdependencies in how some methods work. Additionally, some methods have asynchronous behaviors.

Understanding these details is important for successful integration. Details for these APIs can be found out here. One important step before starting the integration is obtaining a developer key. You can find the developer registration link here.

However, the process of gaining developer access can be quite lengthy, with wait times sometimes reaching up to 6 months. To learn more about others' experiences, check out this Reddit post. It must also be noted that Developer access requires an annual audit and approval process from Amazon.

Amazon Access and Refresh token

To call Amazon REST APIs, you need an access token. Access tokens usually expire after 60 minutes. Once expired, you will need to get a new one. To get a new access token, you need a refresh token. The refresh token allows you to generate a new access token. You can learn more about this process in the video below.

Integration Options for SAP and Amazon

There are four main integration approaches between SAP and Amazon Seller Central, each catering to different business sizes and technical capabilities.

The first is Custom integration via SAP CPI, which offers the highest flexibility and control. This is ideal for organizations with strong internal IT teams who can manage the custom mappings and maintain the integration logic. However, it requires a developer account with Amazon, deep API understanding, and ongoing maintenance.

The second option is EDI-based integration, typically used by enterprises already exchanging documents with trading partners. Amazon can be added as another EDI partner, but this method is asynchronous and lacks the real-time granularity often needed for eCommerce. It's simpler in setup but can introduce delays in order sync and inventory updates.

The more modern alternatives include OMS platforms or iPaaS tools. These do not require Amazon Developer ID or developing custom code from scratch. They come with prebuilt connectors and templates that significantly shorten the go-live timeline.

iPaaS is especially attractive for mid-sized businesses looking for real-time integration without heavy IT investment. These tools offer a balanced approach by reducing manual work, improving compliance, and ensuring long-term scalability.

Tip: Prebuilt iPaaS solutions reduce go-live time and long-term maintenance while ensuring compliance.

Planning for Integration Success

Here are key touch-points to consider.

  •  Inventory Sync: Control how much stock you expose to Amazon. Use a dedicated storage location or plant. The available to promise quantity in SAP must be synced with Amazon.

  • Price and Promotions: Mirror your SAP pricing logic on Amazon—including discounts or holiday sales.

 

In this case the price for ASIN B07122C9VC should be set as $8.00. If a Holiday sale is set up in SAP and it creates a discount of 20%, it should set the price to $6.40 automatically on Amazon.

  • Order Sync: Amazon becomes Sold to, Bill To and Payer. Shipping address will depend on FBA / FBM scenario which we will cover in the coming tutorial. 
  • Tracking & Fulfillment: Automatically update Amazon with shipment tracking from SAP.
  • Returns: Credit Memo Requests in SAP reflect Amazon-initiated returns.

Why Getting an Amazon Developer ID Is Tough

Be ready for:

  • Application queues (3–6 months)
  • Annual review cycles
  • Security and PII compliance (non-negotiable)

Amazon enforces strict compliance standards and has recently started working with third-party audit firms to conduct detailed due diligence on all partners using a Developer ID. It’s not that Amazon discourages integrations.

In fact, they support developer-driven innovation, but ensuring regulatory and data privacy compliance remains a top priority.

Final Thoughts

Integrating SAP S/4HANA with Amazon Seller Central is not just about API calls—it’s about aligning two ecosystems. With the right master data, process mapping, and secure API setup, the integration can be seamless and scalable. 20 Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

Here are some frequently asked question on SAP and Amazon integration.

Here are some frequently asked question on SAP and Amazon integration.

  1. What is SAP Amazon Seller Central integration?
    It's the process of connecting your Amazon Seller Central account with SAP so that orders, inventory, and payments can flow automatically between both systems.
  2. How do I connect Amazon Seller Central to SAP S/4HANA?
    You can use Amazon APIs and integrate them into SAP via custom development, middleware like SAP CPI, or use ready-to-use connectors available in iPaaS platforms.
  3. What is Amazon SP-API?
    SP-API (Selling Partner API) is Amazon's new set of REST APIs that let you manage orders, inventory, pricing, reports, and more.
  4. What are the steps to get an Amazon Developer ID?
    You have to apply on Amazon’s developer portal, explain your use case, undergo an approval process, and pass a compliance review. It can take 3–6 months.
  5. What’s the difference between FBM and FBA?
    FBM (Fulfilled by Merchant) means you handle storage and shipping. FBA (Fulfilled by Amazon) means Amazon stores and ships your products.
  6. How are Amazon fees handled in SAP?
    They are mapped to manual condition types in the SAP Sales Order so your financials stay accurate.
  7. Can I use SAP CPI to integrate with Amazon?
    Yes, but you'll need to build custom mappings and have Amazon API expertise.
  8. Is there an iPaaS connector available for Amazon SAP integration?
    Yes, platforms like APPSeCONNECT and others offer prebuilt connectors that work out of the box.
  9. How is inventory synced between Amazon and SAP?
    SAP's Available-to-Promise (ATP) quantity is pushed to Amazon using their Inventory API.
  10. How is ASIN mapped to SAP material master?
    You maintain ASIN numbers in Customer Material Info Records tied to Amazon as a customer.
  11. What’s the process for API authentication with Amazon?
    You use access tokens that expire every hour. When they expire, you generate a new one using a refresh token.
  12. Why does Amazon require annual audits for Developer IDs?
    To ensure data privacy and security compliance, especially with customer (PII) data.
  13. What happens if I exceed Amazon API limits?
    You’ll hit throttling errors and your API calls will be delayed or blocked. It’s important to batch and schedule wisely.
  14. Can I integrate Amazon with SAP without custom development?
    Yes, by using iPaaS or OMS platforms that come with prebuilt SAP and Amazon connectors.
  15. Is EDI a good option for Amazon integration?
    It can work, but it’s not real-time and may miss some detailed data. It’s better suited for simpler or legacy setups.
  16. How do I map Amazon fees to condition types in SAP?
    Create manual condition types for each fee category and link them in the Sales Order during order sync.
  17. What are some common issues in SAP-Amazon integration?
    Token expiries, throttling, PII access, and missing master data (like ASINs or plants) can cause trouble.
  18. How do I reconcile Amazon payments in SAP?
    You can fetch reports via API and map them to your receivables, netting out fees and returns automatically.
  19. What are the best tools for order sync?
    SAP CPI (for custom setups), iPaaS (like APPSeCONNECT), or OMS platforms are great options depending on your needs.
  20. How long does it take to fully integrate SAP with Amazon?
    It can take anywhere from 4 to 20 weeks depending on whether you're building custom or using a prebuilt solution.
  21. Does the solution work for ECC and Amazon too?
    Yes. The same solution can work for SAP ECC too.
